I remember when Erica Johns had written her novel, Fear of Flying, and that character was Isadora Wang, and everybody said, well, we recognize the characters, or is this really you?
And she said, oh my God, how could anybody think that?
It's a fiction, it's a novel, there's nothing true about it.
So I started out with that line and said, you know, I'm a novel, this is fiction, there's nothing true, and people would get really bored.
And then they'd say, how's the baby, and how's your house?
And they wouldn't want to talk about the novel anymore.
So I wised up very quickly.
And now when people ask me that question, I say, well, I hope that people won't be too upset when they see themselves in the novel.
And it seems to have perked everybody out in Washington about whether or not they're going to be in it.
And this is my first attempt at writing a novel, so I really didn't know how it worked.

But when you do sit down to do a novel, at least I did, I didn't think I'm going to take this person and that person and change the color of their hair and their names and then just have them be thinly disguised characters.
I just wrote, I made up people.
But I found that, particularly in the first chapter, which introduces a lot of the major characters, that when I sat down to reread it about a year after I'd written it, I was playing the game.
I was saying, I wonder who I meant that to be, and I wonder who I meant this person to be.
And what it turns out is that you write what you know, and things just come from, you just sort of pull it out of your head.
And in the end, it really is, as Christopher Stollison once said in one of his songs, it's partly truth and partly fiction.
And is it a roman play?
Well, yes and no.
And I thought that I would start out by explaining that to you and then see if you have any questions about the book.

It's coming out toward the end of what is, of my 16 years in Washington, and measurably the most important and exciting year, because the forces that began to gather in the country in the late 17th, and produced Ronald Reagan,
have reached a kind of conclusion of sorts in the intersection this year of two extraordinary bills, the Grant-Rudman bill and the tax bill, both of them being, in their ways, quite radical.
And a radicalism produced, this sounds paradoxical, but it is, I think, produced by kind of sobriety.
But after six years, the Congress decided that the American people weren't quite as conservative as they said they were.
There's a gap between the real and the rhetorical politics in the country.

And that, in fact, the only way to bring discipline to the appetites of the country is with the Graham-Rudman bill, which is, on the one hand, a feat of an irresponsible legislation passed in 20 years, probably.
On the other hand, you have the tax bill that is also, like the Graham-Rudman bill, finally the product of political despair that overcame the country after these last six years.
It's fair that they could free the government from the influence of the government.
The government has come to look upon itself in these last six years.
And in fact, that's been part of it is surprising.
On one hand, the president has done what serious good leaders do.
He has forced the country to ask the answer basic question.
He did not get the answer he wanted.
He said, what kind of government do you want?
And the answer came in after a five-year rolling referendum on budget cuts we wanted constantly to the government we've got.
And I need all this tumultuous shouting about budget cuts in Washington over the last 50 years, 50 years.
It's been really about the customs, margins, and through social security and the margins of food stamps and all the rest.
Second, the country has had to come to terms with the cost of the deficit.
and with the fact that the great that was supposed to happen, which was a self-financed taxpayer in 1981, had not to be self-financed.
And it being produced was not supposed to produce, it was a deficit, which meant that there was no magic bullet for making services of payment.
That was the great promise of the supply fly theory, but if you cut taxes, you would have increased revenues from lower rates.
And therefore, all political choices, all difficult choices, would be nullified.
So the idea of payment and conservatism has gone the way it was such a reason.

In the last year, it's a country rather clean to itself, rather more sober than it was, and certainly a conservative movement which, by the rest of us, has become middle-aged in the last decade or so.

With an autobiography, of course, you know what your story is.
You know what the secrets of events were and so forth.
And I would say a different part of it is treating how you treat within your text real people.
And there's a constant concern.
I mean, particularly, I didn't have any grudges against people.
There was nothing that I wanted to.
So I want to be very careful.
I didn't really want to hurt anybody.

So then you get into a novel and you suddenly say, for 15 minutes, I've got to, you know, I've got, okay, a little bit to begin with because my main character resembled me in the sense that she was a Hollywood sex symbol.
She lost her career at the age of 35, her whole world fell apart, her husband, her studio, everybody turned against her and she moved to Rome, Italy to start a new life and a new career.
And I thought, well, that's fine, because what it will give me is it'll give me an opportunity to have the reader see everything from an American's point of view.

So that everything that Madeline, myself, is my main character, everything that she learns, that it gives me an opportunity to tell the reader as well Italian expressions and the way they, their mentality, the way they think about things and so forth.
I mean, they have to keep a storyline going.

And at a certain moment when my editor and publisher, John Fine, wanted me to, I guess, beat up the storyline or something like that, I sat for days in my living room stunned with all these chapters everywhere thinking, oh my goodness, what do you do?
How do you, you know, how do I remember what,
So yes, it's kind of a difficult thing.
On the other hand, it allowed me to show the real behind the scenes of movie making, which I think must have ring with an authenticity because I really do know it.
And it also gave me a chance to take very famous people off their pedestals.
And perhaps I was a little bitchier than I should have been, but I wasn't ready to do that at all.
Also, all these mad sex things, you see.
So, I mean, a lot of them were based on, shall we say, things that I heard about.

Now, you know, I don't know about writing that in an autobiographical way and say, well, I was invited to this wonderful party.
But in a novel, it worked very well to say, hey, now, is this for real or not?
But actually, it's quite true.

Yeah, well, life is pretty full at the moment.
I'm very fortunate in that after I showed my wild oats, I came back to the love of one man.
And I'm very happily married.
I married a British actor called Donald Burton five years ago.
And we live in Hampstead, which is in London.
I have a lovely English garden.
There's no joy in any garden in the world, like in England or Ireland, where there's not much rainfall.
And at this time, I have a very quiet time to sit and write, and it's lovely.
I have little stores, charming little stores that are from another century right across the street by me.
And also, you know, the thing is that that is pretty isolating work.
And I think it's been a long time just, you know, being by myself and writing.

with Oprah Winfrey and Geraldine Page, and that's based on the famous Richard Wright book.
